A solution to this can be to put everything in 3D in general. You 
know tha=
t the 2D in 3D is simply a plane. You can fake the 2D stuff 
with a plane w=
ith fixed Z=3D0 for example, and the nodes arranged on it.
I am sure that N=
EAT can deal with this without any major performance 
hits or whatever. 

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> As an example=
, consider a variation on Thomas's poker 
implementation. 
> Same as previo=
usly defined except duplicate the 2d & 3d nodes as 
> hidden nodes so as to=
 capture substrate input (SI) to substrate 
> output (SO), SI-to-SI, SO-to-=
SI, and SO-to-SO interactions, since 
> true input nodes can only have one =
input and contain no activation 
> function. In this particular case, these=
 "hidden" nodes are 
> not "true" hidden nodes in that the each have a rati=
onal basis of 
> dimensionality (i.e. same as the corresponding original no=
de).
> 
> In this instance, the hypercube input "from" node could be either=
 
2d 
> or 3d, and the hypercube input "to" node could be either 2d or 3d, =

> giving the following possibilities ("from" + "to"):
> (1) 2d + 2d
> (2) =
2d + 3d
> (3) 3d + 2d
> (4) 3d + 3d
> 
> The question is: How do you deal w=
ith the variation in the 
hypercube 
> input topology, as you loop over all=
 of the possible links in the 
> substrate network computing the associated=
 weight with the 
hypercube 
> network, for the variations in dimensionalit=
y listed above in (1) 
> through (4)?
> 
> Thanks,
>    Andy Carl
> 
>

> > =
space is 2D, the simplest connective CPPN (without additional 
> inputs 
> =
> to boost the evolution) will have 5 inputs (bias node (1.0) 
> counted), =

> > in 3D the inputs will be 7. And this is enough to achieve ANY 
> > fun=
ctionality within the substrate, since the CPPNs complexify. 
The 
> > basi=
c coordinate frames (x1, y1, x2, y2) are passed through more 
> and 
> > mo=
re coordinate frames, creating very complex connective 
patterns.

substrate can have any number of inputs/hidden/outputs, no 
> matter 
> > w=
hat the topology of the CPPN is or the CPPN's input/output 
> > dimensional=
ity. The substrate can scale up to millions of 
> > nodes/connections, but =
its CPPN is still the same. 
> > There are 2 spaces in general - the phenot=
ype space (the neural 
> > substrate) and the genotype space (CPPN). I beli=
eve it is the 
> > phenotype space, that you call "design space". (Am I wro=
ng?)

=
in

provid=
e

nation looks like the CPPN can depend on the substrate 
in

at you exactly mean?
